direction.raw_text: On an expanse of water, calm and undisturbed. After a moment, it begins to ripple as something rises toward the surface. A girl's face breaks through.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The girl, FRANCES, is 16, blond, very pretty: she seems like the most persuasive proof imaginable of God's existence. She swims toward the shore with long graceful strokes... then climbs the steps of the old wood jetty on West Point Beach.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) It wasn't a murder. I think God just died of old age. And when I realized He wasn't any more, it didn't shock me. It seemed natural and right.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) And yet I began to wonder what the minister meant when he said, 'God, the Father, sees even the smallest sparrow fall. He watches over all his children.' That jumbled it all up for me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: The banks of Puget Sound, dotted with elm trees. Frances sits comfortably in the fork of a tree writing in her diary. Towel around her neck, her hair splayed out and drying golden in the sun.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) But still sometimes I found that God was useful to remember, especially when I lost things that were important. 'Please God, let me find my red hat with the blue trimmings.'

direction.raw_text: . FARMER HOME - FAMILY ROOM - EVENING Frances is now reading aloud from her diary, gently swaying back and forth in a rocking chair. An older woman, LILLIAN FARMER, sits opposite on the couch, listening and nodding from time to time. A small suitcase stands by the front door.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: It usually worked. God became a superfather that couldn't spank me. But if I wanted a thing badly enough, He arranged it.

direction.raw_text: appears in the doorway and hesitates, listening to his daughter read.

direction.raw_text: He goes to the door and picks up his suitcase, glances at Lillian. She doesn't look up. He leaves.

dialogue.raw_text: But if God loved all of His children equally, why did He bother about my red hat and let other people lose their fathers and mothers for always?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Bye, baby.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: See you next weekend, Dad.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I began to see that He didn't have much to do about hats or people dying or anything. They happened whether He wanted them to or not, and He stayed in Heaven and pretended not to notice.

direction.raw_text: Frances stands at a podium. Other STUDENTS and TEACHERS sit to either side of her on folding chairs. Above the proscenium is engraved: West Seattle High School. Below that a banner hangs: "NATIONAL HIGH SCHOOL ESSAY COMPETITION, 1931."
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The AUDIENCE consists of parents, students, and local dignitaries. We SEE several shocked faces. Lillian is there also, smiling. Seated next to her is a distinguished-looking woman, ALMA STYLES. Ernest sits on the other side of the auditorium, looking a little worried.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Frances closes her notebook and looks up, waiting for some response. There is a deep shocked silence, then a smattering of applause. Lillian claps enthusiastically, then rises to her feet. In the back a WOMAN also stands.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A stately man sitting next to her, her husband JUDGE BENJAMIN HILLIER, puts a restraining hand on her arm. The woman continues to glare at Frances. Frances stares back, dumbfounded.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I wondered a little why God was such a useless thing. It seemed a waste of time to have Him. After that He became less and less, until He was... nothingness.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I felt rather proud that I had found the truth myself, without help from anyone. It puzzled me that other people hadn't found out, too. God was gone. We had reached past Him. Why couldn't they see it? It still puzzles me.

On a truckbed addressing the crowd -- which carries placards reading: "Organize Now!", "Workers of the World Unite!", and "Elect Kaminski!" stands MARTONI KAMINSKI. By his side, leading the crowd's responses, stands a younger man with sharp piercing eyes, HARRY YORK.

dialogue.raw_text: Seattle is in the news again as a high school junior wins a national competition and a hundred dollar prize with an essay denying God.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: This prompts civic officials to charge that left-wing politicians are encouraging atheism in the city's schools. Miss Frances Farmer was unavailable for comment, but her mother Lillian --
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Farmer, a well-known local dietician, stepped to her daughter's defense.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (emphatically) Frances has not turned her back on the Lord, they're just having a momentary difference of opinion. What child hasn't questioned the Lord's mysteries in order to better understand them? To paraphrase Mr. Voltaire, I may not agree with what she says, but I'll defend to the death her right to say it. Freedom of speech, unlike in the dark countries to the east, still lives in America! And in my home.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Frances carries library books and a small grocery bag. Her hair and skin gleam in the sun. People in their yards stare at her as she passes. She walks on, coming to a group of CHILDREN slightly younger than herself who are playing in front of a union hall. A girl, EMMA, 13, glances up.

direction.raw_text: Frances keeps walking. Harry hurries after her.

dialogue.raw_text: Don't I know you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't believe so.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Sure. You shouted at me in the auditorium when I read my essay.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No, my dear. You must be mistaken.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (barely audible) Oh bullshit.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I beg your pardon?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (to the dignitaries) Listen, I'm still the same girl that wrote that essay, the same girl who went to Russia, and you people aren't proud to meet me at all.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: We TRACK along the side of the theatre. An exit door is thrown open, and Frances storms out. As she does, she trips over an OLD INDIAN BEGGAR. She stops and looks at him. He peers up at her with large forlorn eyes... then holds out his hand. A connection is made. All the anger drains out of her. She gives him money, several bills. He breaks into a wonderful crooked grin. She starts away, hesitates, then hands him the key to the city. He stares at it, bewildered. She strides away toward her limousine, which is now parked with several others at the end of the alley. The CHAUFFEURS are talking and smoking a cigarette. Her chauffeur sees her and hurries to his limo. As it pulls into the street, we see Harry drift back to the curb and stare after it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . WEST POINT BEACH - NIGHT Frances sits on the old wood jetty staring out at the water, the lighthouse... Harry approaches.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She cracks up. Harry laughs at his mistake.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He looks at her thoughtfully, then sits.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Beat.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They start to walk now along the beach. We see Harry's car and the chauffeured limousine parked above.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She shakes her head mischievously... moves backward unbuttoning her coat.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The coat falls.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She kicks off another shoe, sailing it into the water. Frances is zipping off her dress. Harry bends to pick up the first shoe.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Harry watches her, mesmerized. The dress is off.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She skips off down the beach, her dress strewn on the sands. After a moment, from the darkness, we SEE her underclothes fly into view. Harry can restrain himself no longer.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He drops the shoe and runs after her, tearing off his clothes. After a moment, from the darkness, we hear her squeals of laughter.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: ...It's one thing to marry the guy, but did you have to sleep with him?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Shit. I meant the other way around.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (still laughing) Well, the studio told me not to.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Is that why you did it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Who ever thought they'd be right for once? Jesus, Harry... it's a zoo back there -- HARRY You're telling me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Dick... and my mother! She acts like she's on Mars or something -- HARRY Well, she's back to earth now. They're all pretty huffed up about your leaving. I think you better go back, kid.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Forget it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You know, the funny thing is: it's not a great movie. I mean it could've been, but they screwed it up, gave it a happy ending. And all my friends, I know they're going to smile and say they loved it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: If they say they love it, they'll probably love it. Not everybody lies, you know?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (warmly, to him) No, they don't, do they?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Frances, you're a movie star now. If you give them what they want, you can get anything.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't have what they want, Harry. (stares at the water) Harry, will you tell me something? How can I keep making movies when people in the streets are starving?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Some people starve, kid. Until we can do something about it, they might as well see a movie. Makes 'em feel better.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: But I don't want to be like that. I want to do something... (important)
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What're you gonna do, waste your talent? Why not use it to make something worthwhile. You can do that, you know?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (laughs) Yeah, if I don't make too big an ass of myself.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Tell you what. Let's ditch the limo. Let me drive you up to that red carpet in my beat up Chevy.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The hell you will, Harry York.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Come on, Cinderella, your pumpkin awaits.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (like a clock striking) Bong... bong... bong...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Don't start, Farmer.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (dropping her scarf) It's midnight, Harry. My glittering raiments are dissolving.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (nervously) The chauffeur. He's watching.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He deserves a show. He missed the movie.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm serious, Frances. This is important.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (kicking off a shoe) I know.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: A single glass slipper left glittering on the pearly sands. Who was that girl, anyway?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: 'Come and get it,' Harry.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (excited) Hot damn!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: The street outside the Studio Main Gate. Actors, directors, etc. arrive in their shiny expensive autos. Among them is Frances in her old battered Ford. She waves to the Guard and drives through.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As Frances pulls into her parking space, Claire, the woman from the photo session, strolls up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They walk toward the dressing room.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Claire is laughing. They go inside.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Hi Frances, got a minute?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Sure, Claire. If you don't mind walking my way.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (nervous) Well, I suppose I should just say it. It's your clothes.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (bewildered) My clothes?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah, I mean slacks... and work clothes... and that awful car -- FRANCES It's a perfectly good car. It runs.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes, but... Really, I hate to sound... it's just that the public expects something different from its stars. People won't take you seriously.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't care if my clothes are taken seriously. Or my car.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You know what I mean.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Uh-huh. You mean what if the public finds out I perspire? And wear slacks. And drive an old jalopy? What if they find out I'm a real person. Oh no! Say it ain't so! Not a real person!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Posh, fit for a star. Frances smiles at the MAKEUP MAN.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As Frances sits at the table and Eddie goes to work:
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Morning, Eddie.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's not all, Frances. Mr. Bebe is very concerned about your politics. He hears you've been donating money, speaking at rallies.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yup. Claire... please, please tell Mr. Bebe that if he worried half as much about his scripts as he does about my private life, we'd make a lot better movies.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm sorry, Frances. It's my job, you know?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I know. (imitating Bebe) 'This is a factory and we each have our jobs. The writer writes, the director directs, and the actress...'
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (laughing) ...acts. I'll relay your message.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Dick is talking on the phone in the living room.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He hangs up. Immediately the phone rings again. He stares at it wearily, then answers:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Through the half-open door to the bedroom we see Frances dozing, an open script laid out beside her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He hangs up. Stares off. Slowly enters the bedroom. Frances looks up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Frances looks stricken. Dick presses on.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Dick is crumbling inside.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We watch it sink in. Confusion... self-pity... building gradually to resentment and rage. He starts to throw a tantrum. Hurling things around the room. Frances just sits there.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He hurls a pillow against the wall and rushes out. Frances looks after him, then turns. She's now facing the bureau.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A mirror sits on top of the bureau. She looks into it. Doesn't like her expression. Turns the mirror away.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : OMITTED FADE IN:
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Yes, of course she'll make a statement on women's rights. Call back tomorrow, okay?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (pointedly) Dwayne Steele's residence.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes. (confused) What...? (hurt) Yes. Yes, I'll tell her.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You learn your lines?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (nods drowsily) Sort of.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: There've been some calls.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Who?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well... about half an hour ago that woman from the talent department called, what's her name?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Claire?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah, Claire. She said she was fired. Too bad, huh?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (apprehensively) Fired?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah. She said she delivered your message and that you'd understand.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: There was another call too. From your agent. He says your summer stock deal is all set. So you're going back east, huh?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ...Yes.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Without me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (sighing) Showdown.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You weren't going to tell me, were you? Just pack up and leave, is that it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Dick, we need some time apart -- DICK Hey, I'm not a complete fool, you know. I can see you're going sour on me, and when I try to do something about it, you turn your back and say it's nothing.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Dick, I can't even breathe here...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Dwayne! I'm Dwayne now! And you damn well better get used to it!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (softly, remembering) Dick...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't suppose it occurred to you that I might want to leave too, that I might want to do theatre? No, 'cause you don't want me along, do you? And the reason has nothing to do with summer stock.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No. It's all about that night, isn't it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (bewildered) What night?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The premiere. I never pressed you about it but god damn it, you're gonna tell me right here and right now what happened and where the hell you were!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (quietly) You want his name?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What...?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: My God... I think you're overplaying this a bit...?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Goodbye, Dick.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: A playbill in a theatre lobby reads: "Mt. Kisco Playhouse, 1937 Summer Season: 'THE PETRIFIED FOREST'." Among the names listed is: "Frances Farmer, the 'Come And Get It' Girl. Suddenly we HEAR an eruption of applause.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: on two men: HAROLD CLURMAN -- a thoughtful aristocratic man -- and CLIFFORD ODETS, who is taller, slimmer, with black hair and intense dark eyes. Around them we see (mostly HEAR) the AUDIENCE going crazy, leaping to its feet, yelling "Bravo! Bravo!" Clurman and Odets sit impassively. As the hurrahs die down and the audience files out, the two men sit there. Finally Clurman turns to Odets. Odets nods very slightly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Frances sits in the cramped room, listening intently to Clurman. Occasionally she sneaks a glance at Odets, who is pacing like some caged beast.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Odets is pacing furiously, seizing their attention. He stops, looks at her, then resumes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He stops. Tentatively, almost boyishly, he smiles. She returns it. She's charmed.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: The Group is more than a theatre company. It's the embodiment of an ideal. Our approach allows the actor to be an artist in the fullest sense, a creative individual and an instrument of change. You see -- FRANCES (watching Odets) Really, Mr. Clurman, you don't have to sell me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Forgive my indulgence. Seems we always lecture those who are on time for those who are tardy. The point is, Mr. Odets here has written a wonderful play. Most of the roles are cast, but we haven't found our female lead...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Who is she?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: She's a tramp from Newark.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Forgive me, but I think you'd be perfect for the part.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Miss Farmer, for me this is not a play: it's an assault... a seduction... a plea for understanding. I think we live in a time when new art works should shoot bullets... and you make very attractive ammunition.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And what's the title of this seduc... assault?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (mysterious, intimate) 'Golden Boy.'
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: It reads "Golden Boy". Crowds of people streaming out of the lobby. A sign over the box office reads: "Tomorrow's performances sold out." Odets sits on the curb. Behind him the lights in the theatre lobby flicker off. PEDESTRIANS stroll by: an odd mix of affluent theatre crowd and 1930s bums. Frances emerges from the theatre, sees him sitting there. Sits beside him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He nods.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Another nod. He's silent. He peers up the street. A GIRL, 16, selling pencils catches his eye.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She looks like a waif: tough, vulnerable, pleading with a WEALTHY COUPLE, following them down the street. A drama being played out in the distance, out of earshot.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Frances watches the girl.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: INT. WORKING CLASS BAR - LATER The same conversation continuing:
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Hi.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You wanted to talk?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You see that girl?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's who my play is about.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's me, Clifford.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (strong) I know, but I'm not seeing it. It's there, Frances, the fire is there, but it's not coming through. You're lazy --
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm not!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes, you win them, you bring them into your heart, touch them, but you don't set them on fire!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: But I want to. I'm trying!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I need an incendiary! An arsonist!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Then show me! That's what I'm here for, to learn, to grow!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Good. Then it's very simple. You have to stop being afraid, Frances. It's in you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Clurman is delivering a speech in the background as PHOTOGRAPHERS snap pictures. Behind them on the platform Frances and Odets continue their conversation in whispers:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We now HEAR Clurman's speech. The initial words below were background to the above. What we HEAR now is underlined:
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I can see it. You just have to let it out. Trust it. No one will quash you here, but it's still a fight, a struggle! Being true to your art, being honest, is always a struggle!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ...Not only an artist, but an instrument of change. We must look to the world around us, not content to observe, but to take an active hand in redressing its wrongs. We will not stand idly by as Fascist bombs obliterate democracy. We contribute our profits, for if fascism is not stopped in Spain, it will spread across Europe, jeopardizing the struggle of civilized man to survive. (presenting check to SPANISH CONSUL) The artist, to be vital, must be a soldier too.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm not afraid of struggle, Clifford.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes you are. We all are. The first step is to acknowledge our fear.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: They're walking. The conversation continues.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She is seething. Gorgeous. Alive. He smiles, watching her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As she feels the anger coursing through her body she realizes what he's talking about. She looks at him, still breathing heavily. Gradually her face turns toward a smile. He reaches out and, with exquisite tenderness, kisses her.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Face it! Confess it! You're weak!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm not!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You're afraid!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm not!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You don't want to show your whole soul -- ugly, mis-shapen, and pitiful -- you don't want to show it -- FRANCES (angry) God damn it, Clifford, will you shut up! I tell you, I want to give these things! I want to give them to the audience, and I can give them, I will give them, so shut up!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Good, good. Give them that.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Later. They enter slightly drunk, laughing. He takes her coat.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She's looking at the apartment. He sees her. A dark thought flickers across his face, and he breaks into an exaggerated act:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She starts to put on her coat. He watches her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He opens the bedroom door.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Madam...?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Thank you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh my God! Frances, I'm such a cad. I can't go through with this. My wife is in Europe, but this is her house... (gesturing off) her bedroom. I can't ask you to...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (playing along) Oh well. I guess I better leave then.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Okay, but come here first.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Huh.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (Leading her down hall) Come here. I want to show you something.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: The bed is drawn back, and the sheets are sprinkled with rose petals. Frances' eyes are large. The kiss is very hungry now.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . BEBE'S PANELLED OFFICE - HOLLYWOOD - DAY Bebe's huge desk. Variety Headline: "ACTRESS FIGHTS FASCISM!" Next to the newspaper are a dozen pencils which Bebe is lining up precisely parallel. His expression is totally obsessive, crazed. Behind him a woman (TORA) is cutting his hair. A STUDIO LAWYER paces nearby.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Tora is massaging the back of Bebe's neck. He's oblivious.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: During this conversation, Bebe has been drawing on the Variety. We now see his work. Beneath the headline was a photo of Frances, on whom Bebe has drawn a mustache.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: And on top of her political activities, now she's got a lawyer. She wants out of her contract, Mr. Bebe. She says she's through with motion pictures.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (muttering) I'm sure it wasn't me, it wasn't me...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Excuse me, sir?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't know who she fucked to get where she is, but I don't think it was me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (startled) Well... you could always dump her, Mr. Bebe. Teach her a lesson. There are a million beautiful girls out there who don't give a damn about politics.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's not the point. Frances Farmer has the world by the tit because of this studio, and now she thinks she can waltz off without a thank you. No. No, that young lady has a contract, and she's going to honor it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh. I mean, good.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I think it's time to take the gloves off. (scowls, speaks into intercom) Get me some reporters. (afterthought) Particularly Louella Parsons!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . BELASCO THEATRE - NIGHT The marquee for "Golden Boy" reads "Held Over". USHERS are opening the glass doors from the empty lobby onto the street. We HEAR thunderous applause from the inside.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Frances emerges from the stage door to a throng of AUTOGRAPH SEEKERS. She smiles tiredly, but good-naturedly complies. A little ways back stands a boyish YOUNG MAN holding a single red carnation. When the Autograph-seekers are satisfied and all but a few have trailed away, the Young Man steps forward.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He shyly hands her the flower.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She smiles and begins to walk away. The Young Man follows her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Again she walks on. He follows.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Frances stops walking, her eyes shoot to the Young Man's face.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Young Man suddenly seems much older, and there is no sign of the awkward boyishness.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Young Man grins.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He begins to walk away.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He is gone.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Miss Farmer... I've never done this before... but... I had to tell ya' you're great!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Thank you very much. I'm glad you liked the play.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm really sad it's closing. Now what am I gonna do on Tuesday nights?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You can always come see it in London.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Only if you were in it. Are you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I wouldn't miss it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Boy, I'd love to... but I'm going to Hollywood.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (smiling) Are you an actor?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hell yes!... well, okay, I'm still in school. But as soon as I graduate... California, here I come!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (after a pause) Are you really serious? About acting?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Why... yes.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Then don't go to Hollywood.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Why?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm telling you straight, if you have any serious ambitions, stay clear of the place. It'll crush you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You sound as if you hate it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No, I don't hate it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Aren't you ever going back?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ...Not if I can help it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Gosh! You'll break a lot of hearts.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: They'll mend.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (after a pause) What about your husband?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Will you be getting back together? When you quit Hollywood, I mean.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What is this?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Is it true you're getting a divorce? Comrade?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Why, you... you little bastard!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Thanks for our chat, Miss Farmer. Be seeing you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Just one minute...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (turning) You're wasting your time, lady. Nothing's off the record with me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . WORKING CLASS BAR - NIGHT Odets sits at a table in back, drinking and writing in a notebook. Frances comes up to him. He smiles, draws her to him for a hug.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She hesitates, still affected by the incident outside the theatre.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She nods, turns her back to him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She is crying.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: How'd it go?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: 'But how do I know you love me?'
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Your big speech?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: 'How do I know it's true? You'll get to be the champ. They'll all want you, all the girls! But I don't care. I've been undersea a long time. When they'd put their hands on me I used to say, "This isn't it! This isn't what I mean!" It's been a mysterious world for me! But Joe, I think you're it! I don't know why, I think you're it. Take me home with you.'
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (smiling) I already have.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: How's it sound?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The speech? Real good.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You think I got it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You got it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah. Yeah, tonight I think I got it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . ODETS' APARTMENT - DAY Frances comes in the front door with a bag of groceries, removes her key. Walks into the living room, stops short. Clurman is sitting on the couch, a bottle and two glasses in front of him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She sits.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He pours. She drinks hers, watching him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Frances looks like she's been punched in the stomach.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She collapses back into her seat. Her head is swirling.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She's glaring at him. He hands her a letter.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Her eyes fill with rage. She hurls her drink in his face.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He stands and, with as much dignity as he can muster, leaves. Frances is shaking. She rips open the letter he gave her. Stares at it in horror...
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Hello, Harold.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (nodding) Frances.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (looking around) Where's Clifford?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He's not here.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Bourbon?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What's up?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I hear you're meeting with the studio lawyers to get out of your contract.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's right. I don't want them breathing down my neck while we're in London.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well... well, you see, that's the point. You won't be opening in London.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (insecure) You don't think I'm good enough?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What?! Good Lord no, it's just... It's money. We needed backing and... well, we found it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Who?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: An actress.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: A rich actress.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes. That's the deal. She plays Lorna.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (growing angry) But... but wait a minute. We're supposed to be different, right? Clifford says... This theatre is supposed to be different! And this play... this play is all about what greed and money do to people!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I know, but -- FRANCES (over his line) What does Clifford say?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Right now we have to be practical.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Does Clifford even know? (off his silence) You didn't tell him, did you? (standing) I'm gonna tell him. Where is he?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He knows, Frances.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (gently) He approved it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm very sorry, but... well, Hollywood wants you back, right?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Prick!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . BOOKIE JOINT - DAY Plain room. A few tables with phones, men on the phones writing down numbers. Behind them are blackboards with horses' names and prices. Off to one side Harry is conferring with the OWNER.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A Man at one of the phones looks up, calls.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Harry nods, startled. The Man at the table holds up the phone and goes to his next call. Harry takes the phone.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Of course it can be done, "Mr. Jones," but it's how you do it. There's a way to pay off L.A. cops and a way to get yourself arrested. First you gotta know who to approach --
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You Harry York?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . ODETS' APARTMENT - NEW YORK - NIGHT Frances on the phone. A half-packed bag lies on the bed. A bottle and glass sit beside her. She's been crying and drinking.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Harry? Harry, where are you?!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) Jesus, Frances, how'd you find me?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I called your god-damned office! I want you to kill him, Harry. You'll do that for me, won't you? I loved him, I loved him... that bastard.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . BOOKIE'S OFFICE - NIGHT HARRY Calm down, Frances.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) Don't tell me what to do, just give me his head on a platter!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . ODETS' APARTMENT - NEW YORK - NIGHT Frances unfolds the crumpled letter Clurman gave her.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Two lines! Two fucking lines! 'My wife returns from Europe tomorrow. I can't see you any more.' Just like that!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) Frances...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (sobbing) Harry, I hate being in love. I don't ever want to be in love again. I just hate it!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . BOOKIE JOINT - DAY With the patter of the bookie taking bets beside him, Harry listens to Frances' sobs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He HEARS a CLICK on the other end. He hangs up and heaves a long slow sigh.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I know, Frances... I know.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Frances, in a pair of overalls, falls face down into mud.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We SEE the slate: 'Flowing Gold', Scene 31A, Take 11... then the same action is repeated from a slightly different angle. Next to her is an old car, its wheels mired in mud.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Slate: Take 12. She falls again, this time splattering mud all over her face and hair. She lies still for a moment, gritting her teeth. Sitting comfortably in a nearby director's chair is a DIRECTOR reading Daily Variety. The headline reads: "STUDIO WINS FARMER WAR ON HOLLYWOOD." Behind the Director, off to one side, stands Bebe. The A.D. tugs on the Director's sleeve: A.D. How was that?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Director glances toward Bebe, who nods with satisfaction. Frances watches this interaction. She hesitates, then approaches Bebe. She wipes some mud from her face and drops it at her feet.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She turns and walks, with an air of pride, to her wardrobe trailer.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (looking up) Good, good. One more time.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (standing) For God's sake... why?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Because we want to get it perfect... just the right combination of fury and confusion. You can understand that, can't you, Miss Farmer? We're serious artists here, right? Right.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Look, Mr. Bebe, you can hold me to my contract, but you can't break me. I'm back, and I'm gonna make the best of it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (somewhat snidely) I'd like nothing better.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . ELEGANT BEACHFRONT HOME - NIGHT Lights everywhere. Cars line the driveway. We HEAR the SOUND of a large party. A car pulls up. BOB BARNES gets out, goes around to open the door for Frances. She's exhausted. She doesn't move.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She nods, takes a few. They head for the door.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Well... come on.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: This is a mistake. No. This is a disaster.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Come on, it's just what you need! Let everyone see you. Talk to them, live it up!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (tiredly) But we've been at it since six this morning. At least you could've let me go home and change.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Look, Frances, I didn't want this job. Think I'm crazy? But you begged me: improve your image. So please... lemme try, huh?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (getting out) You're right. I'm sorry. (sighs) Okay, let's go get 'em.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (taking pills from pocket) Here, take a few of these. Studio makes 'em in the basement. They keep the fat off.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (joking) So not only am I a troublesome bitch, but I'm fat too?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Come on. They make you feel nice and peppy.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: The DOORBELL CHIMES. The hostess, CONNIE, a pleasant-looking woman, answers the door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As they embrace, Frances looks around with trepidation:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Barnes tries to pull Frances inside. She sees a flurry of waiting faces. Everyone's watching her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Barnes nods, concerned, and crosses to the bar.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Some people seem amused, some curious, some scornful. The Director from the mud scene nods to her. Connie is at her side for support. A voice from somewhere pierces the chatter:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As Barnes returns with her drink, she turns to Connie:
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Hi! Bob Barnes! Looks like a swell party!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (pleased) Frances!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (whisper) God, who's here?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (also whispering) The usual vermin, I'm afraid.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (sotto voice) Get me a drink.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hi everybody.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: So nice to have you back, Frances.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Connie, can I use the upstairs bathroom?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Sure.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Later. Frances lies in a bubblebath, relaxing, sipping her drink. She obviously feels a lot better. Someone knocks.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Come in.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: stares at her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He is dumbfounded. He slowly retreats into the hall.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (relaxed) Hi.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Barnes is talking to a Young Man whom we recognize as the reporter who tricked Frances in New York.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He nods toward a hard-faced OLDER WOMAN surrounded by admirers.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: You wouldn't believe the offers! Just piling in. I mean piling. Some of the best scripts I've read in years!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (sarcastic) Yes? My employer will be glad to hear that.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Louella? Is she here?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: How could you miss her?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Louella's here and I'm talking to you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: We SEE the open door to the bathroom. Frances, with a towel around her, is going through Connie's closet. Barnes KNOCKS.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Frances pulls down a dress and inspects it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He nods and retreats out the door.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Frances? (enters, sees her) Oh no.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Refill my drink, will you, Bob?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (aghast) What're you doing?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Putting on my armor.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Come on, Frances. Louella Parsons is here. She wants to talk to you, help you out.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (musing) Louella... didn't she call me a spoiled little bitch?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Come on, she's an important columnist! What's the matter? I thought you wanted these people to forgive you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (darkly) 'Forgive'...? For What?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm sorry... that was an unfortunate choice of words.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You're not kidding. (firmly) Get me a refill, Bob. I'll be down in a minute.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Everyone chattering away... then hushing slightly. Heads turn: Frances is descending the stairway in one of Connie's dresses. She looks absolutely radiant... like some kind of goddess. Barnes, looking very pleased at her appearance and the others' reaction, hands her the drink.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Then the Young Reporter steps forward.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Frances bristles. Barnes looks on nervously: It's all becoming unravelled again.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Frances is broiling. She stares at him. Under her steady gaze, the snide smile gradually fades from his face.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He blanches. This hits home. Frances turns on her heel and leaves.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Thank you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (his callow youth act) Gee, awful good to see ya again, Miss Farmer.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: My employer would like to know something very important: is it true your friend Clifford sleeps in the nude?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You seem like an intelligent young man.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Huh?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Can't you find a more dignified way to make a living?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Frances rushes out, followed by Barnes and a few curious partygoers. She is very upset. Tight. Holding it in. Barnes pleads with her, tries to stop her, but she leaps in the car and speeds off, spewing gravel over him. The partygoers salute her with their drinks.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: In the pale moonlight we SEE the dim outline of a poster tacked to the outside wall. The highway disappears down to the sea glittering dully in the distance. We HEAR the RISING SOUND of an approaching car. Its headlights crest the hill, illuminating the poster, showing a woman driving an open car, seated beside the outline of a familiar mustached figure. The poster reads, "When You're Riding Alone, You're Riding with Hitler." The lights grow brighter, almost blinding. The car, accelerating furiously, flashes by. Then we HEAR a motorcycle start up. It emerges from the blackness and speeds off in pursuit. A roadsign reads: "Dimout Zone." Frances drives fast, tears running her face. The MOTORCYCLE COP pulls up alongside and shouts, "Pull over!" She hesitates. He waves insistently. Gradually she slows. He gets off his bike and walks over, preparing the usual lecture.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He leans over the car and sees Frances, her hair wild and tangled.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She switches her headlights back on.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She starts the car. The Cop, angry now, lunges in and grabs the keys.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She leaps out of the car. The Cop turns off the car lights. As Frances passes his motorcycle, she switches on its lights.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He runs after her, turning off the motorcycle lights on the way. When he catches her, he grabs her arm. She struggles, grabs the flashlight from his belt. She switches it on and holds it high, its beam spearing wildly out to sea. He lunges for it, knocks her down. They struggle. He rolls on top of her, pinning both her arms with one hand... trying to handcuff her. She writhes, knees him in the balls. She crawls away, desperately clawing at loose stones. The Cop, angry now, hurls her down again and manages to get the cuffs on. As they dig into her wrists, she tries to bite him. The Cop, winded from the battle, yanks her to her feet and drags her, kicking and screaming, to his motorcycle. He pulls out his radio mike.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Okay...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (a come-on) Hey, where's the fire, sister?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (sarcastic) In my eyes, officer.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Cool off, beautiful. Didn't you see the sign says "Dimout Zone?" (switching off her lights) There's a war on, you know?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Come on. You're seriously trying to tell me the Japs can't find Los Angeles without my headlights?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (testy) I didn't make the law, lady. I just enforce it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: God, you bore me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Don't touch me!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hey!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (panting) Santa Monica, this is motor six-sixty- six. I got a live one here.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . BEACH HOUSE BALCONY - DAY CLOSE ON front page of the Los Angeles Times, October 1942. The headlines read: "24 Jap Ships Sunk", "Errol Flynn Sex Trial Delayed", "Frances Farmer Arrested on Drunk Driving Charge -- Actress Gets $250 Fine and Six Months Probation."
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: to show several newspapers spread out on the balcony of Frances' beach house. As the papers ruffle in the wind, a little kitten swipes at them. Frances sits in the sun writing in her diary, the same one we saw at the opening of the film. A man's shoes COME INTO VIEW.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She turns, surprised and pleased to see him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He walks off into the kitchen. She puts her diary away.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Harry returns, sipping the drink.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She smiles.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She laughs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Beat.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We see a thought come to him.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (O.S.) Got any ginger beer?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Take a look.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (calling) How the hell do you find me anyway?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (O.S.) Animal magnetism! (she laughs) No ginger beer. What's this red stuff?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What's left of my blood.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (O.S.) Think I'll have a glass.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Help yourself. Everyone else has.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Very tasty.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (looking around) Nice joint. Can you afford it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Nope. The studio pays. Thank you, Harry.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What for?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: For not chopping off his head and serving it to me on a platter.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, I would have, you know? I just didn't know how to cook it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Six months' probation...? You gotta learn when to do battle, Farmer. You're not going to win many bouts with 200 pound cops.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I took the early rounds.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (laughs) I'll bet.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't know. It hurts, Harry. Some things, no matter what you do with them, they just hurt.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: So you drink, and you fight with a cop...?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah, and you look at people and you wonder who the hell they are, what's going on inside their heads. Sometimes you can hear it, like a buzzing, the things that happen in their heads. And you wonder: does anybody ever love anybody, really?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Beats me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I gotta get outta here. I gotta get out of this town.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hey look, I got some business down in San Diego. Whattaya say you come with me, stay a few days?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No, Harry, I can't -- (right now)
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You're coming.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . SAN DIEGO BAR - NIGHT Waterfront bar, full of SAILORS, WHORES, and HEAVY DRINKERS. Hanging over the bar is San Diego paraphernalia. Frances and Harry sit at a table. Heavy boozing has led to philosophizing:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He grunts: what?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: In the background, we SEE a DRUNKEN SAILOR lurching toward their table.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Sailor trips and falls across their table, spilling beer on Frances and knocking things over.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Sailor goes berserk, takes a swing at Frances. Harry leaps in to protect her, starts to fight with the Sailor. Frances joins in; she's not going to let anyone fight her battles. The Sailor's BUDDY enters the fracas. Everyone's getting hit. As the melee continues we:
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: You know... when I started acting, you know what I wanted?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I just wanted to be part of something... one thing, one play or one movie, something that was really fine... memorable. And I could say: I did that, I made something good.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well... to get a crack at something good, you gotta earn it, you gotta climb the ladder first. So you do, you work hard, and all these people behind you are pushing you up, shouting you on. And then one day you realize you are, you're at the top... and there's nothing there. And you look behind you and there's no one below. You're just left there all alone... swaying in the god-damned breeze.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, like the man said: "You can make a fresh start with your last breath."
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (irritated) Hey, watch it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (eyeing her suggestively) Watch what?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Get away from me, you foul slime.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's no way for a lady to talk.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Take a walk, pal.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Who said I was a lady?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Sorry I insulted you... bitch.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hey!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Ahhh, go eat a toilet seat.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: A cab pulls up. Frances gets out. She looks weary and has a bruise on her cheek. A car is parked in the driveway. She frowns at it, shrugs, and carries her suitcase toward the house.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She enters with her bags, then drops them, stunned. The house is stripped bare. A MAN holding a measuring tape comes out of the bedroom.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Frances stares at him, dumbfounded.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: What happened? Who're you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Who're you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I live here.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You're Farmer? Oh... Well, look, they took your stuff out. Moved it to some hotel, I think.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm preparin' it for the next tenant, he's coming in tomorrow.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Frances on the phone. Boxes spread out, their contents strewn over the floor, tables, etc. Frances is going through various piles, again and again, looking for something...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She takes a long drink, sifts through a pile, then throws it on the bed in disgust. We HEAR a voice on the phone.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She slams down the phone.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (muttering) God damn it, god damn it... (into phone) Yes, I'll wait, I'm waiting... (to herself) I don't believe this. They can't do this to me!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (into phone) Barnes? It's my diary! They stole my fucking diary! Find it, will you? Find it! God damn it, that's my life!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: The crew is idle and the Director paces, muttering:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Frances, looking pretty hung-over, enters blithely.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Director clenches his fists as though about to punch her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She walks to her dressing room as the Director explodes anew.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Never. Never again. I swear, I swear I will never work with this broad --
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You're four hours late! It's insane! It's unprofessional!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'd say I'm behaving as professionally as anyone else in this town.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Where were you?!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Terribly, terribly sorry; I overslept. What's the name of this fine entertainment we're all so involved in?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (looking blearly at the slate) Oh yes. "No Escape." That's it. There's no escape.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Small, cramped; not like the earlier one we saw. The Hairdresser -- whom we recognize as Tora, the woman who cut Bebe's hair -- stands waiting, holding her brushes and looking vexed. Frances enters.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Frances sits. Tora begins brushing her hair, yanking Frances' head back with each stroke. Building tension...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Frances cries out and twists around suddenly. Tora is thrown back: stumbling... falling... hitting her jaw against a chair.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She storms out. Tora is left moaning, holding her jaw.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: It's about time! You're not the star on this show, y'know!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Of course, it's not up to me to say anything. I'm just crew... Y'know, you hair's so fine you'll lose it if you're not careful. Wonder you all don't, the things you do to yourselves. In fact, I think you are already... Fact, I think you better --
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's it! I'm not taking this any more! I quit!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Frances marches across it. Everyone stares.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: When she reaches the exit door, she turns and bows to them all, grandiloquently.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Goodbye!... goodbye!... goodbye!...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: She's snoring in bed. Face down, spread-eagled. The light is on. A whiskey bottle (three-quarters empty), a tumbler (three- quarters full), and a bottle of pills sit on the night table. The phone RINGS. She winces, groans, tries to open her eyes then squeezes them together: hung over. Her arm flails out, finds the light and turns it off.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The phone keeps RINGING. Her arm gropes for it. A loud POUNDING at the door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The POUNDING at the door becomes violent. Someone's breaking it down.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The door splinters.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Men stream into the room. Back-lit from the hall they look like monsters, phantoms. They're carrying sticks. Frances screams and runs naked into the bathroom.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She slams the door on the advancing figures.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Shit.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What the hell's going on here? (calls) Hold on! (answering phone) Hello... (we HEAR a dial tone) Hello?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hey!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What...? Help!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Don't kill me! Don't kill me!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Frances leans her weight against the door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's too much for her. She's shoved back, falling to the floor. The door flies open revealing THREE LARGE COPS. Leering at her. Frances clutches at the shower curtain, trying to cover herself.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Mama, help me, help me, Mama! Don't let them kill me!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Get your clothes on.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (crying) You have no right! You have no fucking right, you bastards! Get the hell out of here -- COP Get your clothes on, lady -- FRANCES GET OUT!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You're under arrest.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . SANTA MONICA POLICE STATION - NIGHT Frances is being led to the booking desk. All around her Photographers snap her picture, and Reporters walk alongside subjecting her to a never-ending barrage of questions. Frances just smokes a cigarette and smiles grimly at the dour-faced SERGEANT facing her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Photographers laugh.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Frances considers for a moment, then smiles matter-of-factly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Sergeant reddens. Frances laughs as the Photographers snap their shots.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Name?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't believe this! You jerks drag me down here in the middle of the night and you don't even know who the hell I am!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Age?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Fifteen.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (bristling) Address?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Just put me down as a avg -- a vagrant vagabond. Come on, this is a joke! Assault and battery? I barely touched that bitch!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Occupation?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Cocksucker.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: escort Frances to her cell. She shakes their hands off her arms and enters. They slide the door shut. Photographers press up to the bars. Frances calls after the matrons.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Frances looks disgustedly at the Photographers and lies down heavily on the cot.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Hey! I'd like to leave a wake-up call for say, ten? Hey! I'll have my bread and water in bed!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hey Frances! Why don't you comb your hair, okay?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ...Take me the way I am.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Frances, looking disheveled, dazed, and over-tired from a sleepless night in jail, stands alone before the JUDGE. Next to the PROSECUTOR sits Tora, her jaw heavily bandaged, glaring at Frances. The spectator's section is packed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Suppressed laughter ripples through the courtroom.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Frances moves closer to the bench.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The courtroom erupts into surprised laughter.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Frances laughs triumphantly and spears the air with her finger, pointing at the Judge.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The laughter grows. The Judge bangs his gavel.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Judge pounds his gavel. Frances is about to say something when suddenly the realization of what's happening hits her. The Judge is leaving the bench. A REPORTER runs out of the room.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Judge ignores this.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Judge closes his chambers door behind him. Frances turns slowly. The Matrons are coming toward her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She lunges at the Matrons, trying to get past them.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: ...Is that not true?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (under her breath) Who's writing this guy's lines?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Answer the question! Have you driven a car since you were placed on probation?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No, I couldn't get my hands on one.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Have you reported to your Probation Officer as directed?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I never saw him. Why didn't he show up?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Did you expect him to look you up?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Why, certainly. I wanted to get a peek at his face...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You're on your way to a contempt citation, young lady.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's fine with me... (turning to spectators) Get it? Fine. A fine! Hey c'mon, c'mon, what is this, an audience or a jury?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Miss Farmer, is it true you fought with the policeman who arrested you last night?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Sure it's true. I was fighting for my country as well as myself.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Miss Farmer, you were advised at the last hearing that if you took one drink of liquor or failed to be a law-abiding citizen --
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Are you telling me you didn't have a little rum in your pineapple juice this morning? I can smell it from here, Your Honor.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's enough!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's the truth! I can smell it from here -- you old hypocrite!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Miss Farmer! In light of your flagrant disregard for the conditions of your probation, coupled with the unwarranted assault on the Plaintiff here... I am forced to order you to begin serving a sentence of 180 days in the County Jail.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Fine!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (rising) You are a deeply troubled young lady... I only hope you change your course before it's too late.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (frightened now) Wait a minute... I haven't got a lawyer...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (shouting) What I want to know is do I have any civil rights?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I want to make a phone call...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I have a right to make a phone call!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: The Reporter is phoning in his story. The hallway is pandemonium.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: In the next phone booth we SEE Harry listening to the Reporter's spiel. He regards the confusion around him with calm eyes.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (from his notes) "The kleig-lighted road to fame and fortune is strewn with heartbreak and despair. Today film star Frances Farmer, tarnished by alcohol and drugs" -- 'm I going too fast for ya?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: They burst open. The Matrons and Two Cops come out carrying Frances. Reporters and Photographers rush past her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She suddenly sees the phone booths. Her eyes fill with tears, her shoulders slump forward and her lower lip begins to tremble. She no longer struggles.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Matron relaxes her grip and gives Frances a handkerchief. Frances dabs at her eyes... wraps the kerchief around her knuckles... and slugs the Matron in the jaw, sending her sprawling. Frances runs to the phones.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Frances throws herself at the door of the booth. The Reporter is delirious with joy: what a story!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Frances pounds at the door a few more times, then moves to the next booth... into the arms of Harry.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Harry shakes his head. Before he can speak, Frances is grabbed from behind and dragged toward the elevator.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Harry opens the door to his booth. The Reporter looks up at him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Harry says not a word, but punches the Reporter hard in the face. The Reporter sags, out like a light. In the confusion, no one has noticed a thing. Harry pulls the door shut.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: They're stealing my civil rights! Help me! I'm being kidnapped! Oh God, help me! Help me!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (to a Matron) Haven't you ever had a broken heart?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh my God, she's loose!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: She's attacking your correspondent! Right here in the Court Building! Good God, this bitch is crazy! Someone stop her!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (a whisper) Harry!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I have a right! I have a right!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (into phone) With what must surely be the final act of madness, the curtain falls on Frances Farmer's once promising career. The crazed blonde who at 27...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hold it a second, Bub...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Frances is sitting in a wooden chair. The venetian blinds over the tall windows are almost completely closed. The room is dim and terribly quiet. A WOMAN is murmuring something to a kindly-looking JUDGE. Another MAN is standing beside her. Frances can't quite make out the words.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He nods to the other Man who, together with the Woman, turn away from the bench. As they pass in front of one of the tall windows, Frances recognizes the Woman. It is Alma Styles.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She feels an arm slip around her shoulders and she stiffens. Her mother's face appears by hers.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Two other WOMEN appear at either side of Frances and Lillian. Lillian tenderly takes her daughter's face in her hands.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She kisses Frances on the forehead. Frances looks at the two Women. They are smiling understandingly at Lillian. Frances looks a little alarmed.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: ...and we feel that this would be more appropriate.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ...a difficult decision, but, I'm sure, the proper one.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (whispering) It's alright now, little sister, everything's going to be just fine.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Mama, what's...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Shhh, shhh. You're not going to jail, Frances. The Judge has put you under my care. I'll see you get the rest you need.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You're taking me home!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (smiling) First things first, little sister. Trust me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . ENTRANCE DRIVE - DAY A wood-panelled station wagon turns the corner of a tree- lined road and heads up toward tall wrought-iron gates. On a white-washed wall are black letters: "MEADOW WOOD CONVALESCENT HOME". The Station wagon, a similar sign on its door, pulls up. The gates swing slowly open, and it travels up a long tree-lined driveway. As it goes by, we see Frances sitting in the back seat between Lillian and one of the Women from the previous scene. The car heads up toward a large Spanish-style building set back among some trees.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Frances sits in front of a desk nervously smoking a cigarette. Lillian stands at a window looking out at a broad expanse of well-manicured lawn ending at a row of oaks in the distance.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Lillian smiles enthusiastically at Frances, who stares accusingly back: she's not falling for that. An awkward moment of silence. Lillian fidgets, doesn't know what to say. She is rescued when the door opens and DR. SYMINGTON (early 30s, glasses, white coat and ingratiating smile) enters. He holds his right hand out to Frances.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Frances stares at the proffered hand. Lillian steps in quickly and takes it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Doctor winks at Frances and puts a hand on Lillian's arm.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He smiles pleasantly. Lillian is obviously very put off by the idea. She looks at Frances who stares unseeingly out the window.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He goes to the door and opens it. Lillian is momentarily at a loss, but she acquiesces. She bends down and tightly hugs Frances, who pats her on the back a couple of times.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She waits for a reply and then, getting none, starts out the door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Lillian turns back expectantly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Lillian looks to the Doctor, who nods sympathetically at her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She goes out and down the hall. The Doctor closes the door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He reddens ever so slightly and looks away.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Frances' face begins to set in hard planes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He stops as Frances rises and leans over his desk:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Symington stares at her. With a careful, almost scientific gesture he moves thumb and forefinger over his lip, then rubs the two fingers together. Yes, there is sweat.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He pushes a button on his desk and reaches for a folder. Frances hasn't moved. She gazes at him evenly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: His eyes are very calm now, he smiles at her patronizingly.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Why it's beautiful here! What a view!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Good afternoon, Miss Farmer. I'm Dr. Symington.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Good afternoon, Doctor.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm very pleased to meet you, Mrs. Farmer. I'm sure we'll have more of a chance to talk later. Right now I think it's important that your daughter have a chance to settle in. Perhaps it would be best if you said your goodbyes here.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh. Well, I have some background that you should probably know about if you're...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I have no doubt, Mrs. Farmer. If you'll speak to the girl at the desk, she'll arrange an appointment.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'll be back real soon, little sister. You be a good girl.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (staring out window) Mama!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (warningly) ...I want to go home, Mama.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You'll see, little sister. Everything will be fine. The doctors know best.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I find these initial meetings to be much easier without the concerned relatives in attendance.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Am I supposed to say 'thank you'?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Thanks are hardly necessary.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Aw, shucks, ma'am. T'weren't nothin'.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm glad to see you haven't lost your sense of humor.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It ain't for lack of trying.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: So it seems. May we be serious for a moment?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (seductively) Why, Doctor! We've only just met!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I feel I've known you for a long time... you see, I've followed your career... you're a fascinating case... I'm looking forward to resolving your predicament.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh! Are you really?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Among persons such as yourself, creative people under great stress, erratic behavior is not at all uncommon and certainly nothing to be ashamed of. It's just that the neuroses which fuel your talent can also generate certain character disabilities which... (can cripple your ability to function...)
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Do you expect me, for one moment, to believe you have greater insight into my personality than I do?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Please sit down...
dialogue.name: dialogue
