dialogue.raw_text: You may discuss my predicament, Doctor. You may discuss it with anyone you like, but not with me. I'm not interested. I can solve my problems without recourse to a veternarian.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I see.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Besides, I don't want to be what you want to make me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And what's that?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Normal. Average.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: All right. Will you please sit down now? (smiling) Symington says.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ...Did you really say that?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Just a little joke, Miss Farmer.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: This whole thing is a joke!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Stay calm, please.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No, you stay calm, Doctor! But you're finding that difficult, aren't you? (soft, seductive) Why, are you attracted to me? Perhaps later, in some of our more intimate sessions... after we know each other a little better... (turning harder) and you've torn my personality to shreds, and I'm weeping and vulnerable... (very hard) then you'll really get your kicks, won't you, "Doctor?"
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'll have someone show you to your room.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, that's good, very professional. In control. But the tiny beads of sweat on your upper lip give you away.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You really should get some rest now. Nurse will meet you outside. Good day.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Is there something else?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You didn't say 'Symington says'.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Symington says.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Small, white, spartan and rather pleasant. Lillian is standing by the window, testing the locks. She turns and goes to the bed, fussing with the pillow, seeming very uncomfortable. She pulls at the corners of the mattress. The door opens and a tall, sullen-looking MATRON walks in. Lillian doesn't pay much attention to her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Something in her tone makes Lillian look up. The Matron closes the door behind her and advances. Lillian assumes her full height.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Not much on hospital corners, are you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You Farmer?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Frances is walking with a NURSE. They pass a variety of other patients, some of whom look old or beaten but few of whom seem overtly crazy.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Nurse smiles confidentially at her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They get to the door and HEAR Lillian's protesting voice:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They enter and SEE the Matron struggling to get Lillian's coat away from her. Lillian pleads with Frances.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Frances bursts out laughing. The Matron releases Lillian and comes for Frances.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: So this is the nuthouse...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Honey... take my word for it. This is a resort.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (O.S.) You have no right!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Tell them who I am! Tell them who I am!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Are you crazy? Unhand that woman! That's Amelia Earhart!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: -UP OF A HYPODERMIC NEEDLE A little fluid squirts out the tip.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (O.S.) But what is it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Frances strapped down on a white cot. The Nurse is holding the syringe while a THIN NURSE and an ATTENDANT stand by.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Frances looks at her suspiciously, uncertain whether to believe this, and turns toward the Nurse with the hypodermic.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This sounds more reasonable. Frances relaxes somewhat.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Frances does. The Attendant jams a rubber bar between her teeth. Frances squirms, fights. The Attendant holds the bar in place. And the Nurse pushes the plunger on the hypo. Frances goes rigid. Her eyes widen, her back arches. With a loud hoarse cry she starts to convulse. The SCREEN BEGINS TO FADE into bright white light. She is unconscious. The SCREEN IS NOW BLANK.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: You've got to tell me what it is!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's insulin. It throws your body into shock.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (reassuringly) It's just vitamins.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: B-Complex, certain minerals... (inserting hypo) Just stay relaxed... Good, now open your mouth a sec.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Frances sits beside Lillian on a bench. Other patients with ground privileges wander aimlessly about. There is an open carpet bag at Lillian's feet and, in her lap, a bundle of letters and telegrams that she's showing to Frances. Frances seems restless.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She hands it to Frances, who lets it drop beside her on the bench.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Frances sighs. She looks for something to divert her attention.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: ...and here's the one from Duluth. A war widow with five children. She works in a defense plant and she's very worried about you. I answered her that she shouldn't let worry over you affect her vital work; and that you'd be back on the silver screen in no time.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And here's one from nice Mr. Zeiss. He says that...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Why are these all opened?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, they needed immediate answers, Frances. It's good manners and good sense. You shouldn't be bothering yourself with these right now.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Then why did you bring them?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's your fan mail, little sister.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (looking off, under her breath) You kill me, Mama.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Go on...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Frances is alone in the room. The door is ajar. She's standing over Symington's desk, which is empty except for a doodle pad. The doodle she's looking at is extremely bizarre, sadistic... After a moment, Symington ENTERS holding several folders. Frances' manner changes very subtly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Symington puts the folders in a drawer. All except Frances'.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Frances is wrapping and unwrapping a handkerchief around her knuckles. Looks a little crazy. Symington's watching it. She stops.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Frances stares at him. Stunned. Horrified.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Symington smiles patronizingly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She tears open the door. Two huge ORDERLIES are waiting. Frances tries to barrel past, but they easily restrain her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Symington sits forward, his hands smoothing his hair. Frances smiles sarcastically at him:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They haul her away.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: ...I'm sorry to keep you waiting, the staff review ran over. Did you enjoy your mother's visit?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (sitting) Yes. It was very good to see her.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Really? Any problems?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Not at all. She brought me my fan mail. (a performance) I had no idea there were so many strangers concerned about me. But I guess that's the best thing about working in the movies. You make so many friends. I want to go back and show them that the faith they put in me wasn't a mistake.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You're telling me you feel guilty.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (slightly edgy) No... What I mean is... I'm just very excited by the prospect of getting on with my life, that's all.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (after a pause) Do you really believe your mother's trying to kill you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (laughing) What?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: She told me you said, "Mama, you want to kill me."
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I never said... Oh look. That's just a figure of speech. She said something funny, and I said...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And you accused her of tampering with your mail.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh for Christ's...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm sorry. She misunderstood, that's all.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: But you tell me you had a pleasant visit and your mother says you were sullen and uncommunicative. Whom do you think I should believe?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Doctor, I hate to break this to you, but my mother is a little batty.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Frances, you're still filled with anxiety. You feel guilty and hostile toward your family and friends. Consequently, I didn't recommend your release at the staff review.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You what?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Mental illness is an elusive thing, and though I'm pleased you're feeling more... capable, it's perhaps unrealistic to expect you to be completely cured after so short a time. Don't you agree?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (smiling) I'm sure you'll see it my way in the end.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Dr. Symington, how big is your dick?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Huh?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: 'Cause if it's long enough, which I doubt, why don't you wrap it around and fuck yourself in the ass!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I want outta here, you understand? I'm ready to get out! So you go back there... you go back and you tell them to let me out!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (calmly) Frances, I'm warning you...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No, I'm warning you! Who do you think you are, God? You bumble around with your folders... (she knocks her folder to the floor) ...and your pencils... (she grabs some pencils and throws them at him) ...and your god-damn buttons... (she pounds on the inter-com; a voice says, 'Yes, Doctor?') ...all your badges of authority! But you have no authority! You're nothing! You're a zero!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Doc?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Symington says...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (tonelessly) Sedate her.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . MEADOW WOOD CONVALESCENT HOME - DAY A few PATIENTS stroll about, visiting with relatives. Frances lies on a chaise lounge. She's wearing a robe and dark glasses, a big hat, and she seems to be sleeping. THE CAMERA APPROACHES. Her hair is a mess, her skin splotchy. And something is moving: her hand... one finger on one hand is moving in agitated little bursts. We realize she is not sleeping at all...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She looks to one side and sees him. Frowns. Takes off her glasses and runs her fingers nervously through her hair.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (O.S.) Hi there. How 'bout a walk in the woods?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh my God, I look awful.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (friendly) You've looked a whole lot better. C'mon.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Frances and Harry walking in a relatively secluded area. She glances around continuously... suspiciously.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She breaks down and weeps on Harry's shoulder. Harry looks around warily.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Harry nods, squeezes her arm firmly -- a warning -- as a white-coated ATTENDANT APPROACHES. Frances straightens up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Attendant reaches them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Frances starts to move off with the Attendant. For an instant Harry -- and we -- wonder if she really is crazy.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She turns. The Attendant turns. She smiles sweetly, madly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Attendant is between her and Harry. We SEE her face turn dark. She shoves the Attendant toward Harry and shouts:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She runs. The Attendant staggers toward Harry, who knocks him down with two punches. ANOTHER ATTENDANT runs up. Harry whips out an icepick and brandishes it at them:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Attendants hold their ground. Harry runs after Frances.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: They're doin' stuff to me, Harry. Can you see it? You feel it? They're putting stuff in my food or something, my water, and they're using it to put thoughts in my head. You understand? They're trying to re- arrange what's in my head, they're trying to drive me crazy! Oh, Harry!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I can't stay here anymore, you understand? I can't, I can't. I gotta get home. I gotta get somewhere else, anywhere, okay?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, Miss Farmer! Time for your bath, Miss Farmer!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (urgent whisper) Listen: to the left. Straight through the trees and over the wall to your left. My car is there.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (as if to a child) It's time for your bath!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh good. I love my baths.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Come along now.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Frances! Did you hear what I said?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Of course, Harry.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (fiercely) Over the walls!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You want crazy? I'll show you crazy!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Frances and Harry crash through bushes, come to a high wall.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Frances hugs him tightly, kisses him. He lifts her by the waist, and she grabs the top of the wall and hauls herself up. Harry joins her. We SEE, over the wall, a Lincoln Zephyr waiting on a dirt road. Harry and Frances jump down as we HEAR the Two Attendants burst through the underbrush and haul themselves up. As their heads pop over the top of the wall, they see the Lincoln disappearing down the road in a cloud of dust...
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (offering to lift her) Here.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: DUSK - DAY Harry, eyes bleary and shoulders hunched, tries to concentrate on the road ahead. The RADIO DRONES quietly, a lazy saxophone ballad. After a while, there's movement in the back seat and Frances sits up. She yawns and stretches as Harry watches her in the mirror.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Harry smiles. Frances climbs over the seat and starts to fiddle with the radio.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Harry laughs. They pass a poster: "BUY WAR BONDS!" Frances stares at it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Harry looks at her quizzically.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Beat.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She rubs his neck and his attitude seems to soften. She looks at him fondly, thoughtfully.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Evening, gorgeous.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (yawning) That sure looks like fun... (leaning over front seat) You know how long it's been since I was behind the wheel?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Forget it, Frances. You're not driving.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Have I told you how mean you're turning, York?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Where are we, mean man?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Couple hours from Idaho. We'll cut across to Montana. I've got friends there with a ranch.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I should've known...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: This is another one of your schemes to get me off alone...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's right.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (smiling) ...Take advantage of me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't think I'd be much good in a war...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Whattaya think you're in now?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (sleepily) I don't know. Not a war exactly. It's more a... a misapprehension maybe...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Huh?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: A misunderstanding, people taking the wrong meaning from things. I wasn't declaring war, Harry. I was just saying my prayers.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Who to?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Harry, I have to go home. I have to talk to Mama.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Frances, you're fulla drugs. You don't know what you're saying. Who do you think put you into Meadow Wood? Your mother thinks you're crazy and she'll keep on thinking it as long as it suits her.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (sitting up) No, she just didn't want me going to jail, that's all.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah? She's a shark, Frances. I'm not taking you there, and that's that!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You know something, Harry?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I guess.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Aside from meanness, you're almost perfect. There's only one other thing wrong with you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What's that?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You can't drink.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: The Lincoln is parked beside a few other cars.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Frances and Harry sit at a table cluttered with empty glasses. The JUKEBOX PLAYS, a few COUPLES dance. Frances is gulping down a tall Scotch.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He knocks back his drink.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (wincing/grinning) Ohhh, that's lousy Scotch!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (calling drunkenly) Hey! Another shot for the lady and a double for me!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What a man!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hey, you're a good quarter-horse, kid, but you can't go a route of ground.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (hoisting her glass) To quarter-horses.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No. To thoroughbreds.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: A hand puts a nickel in, and we HEAR Bing Crosby singing "Love Is So Terrific." We PAN across the dance floor, where Harry and Frances are dancing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Frances squeals with delight when she hears the song. She holds Harry forcefully and starts to lead him around the floor. Harry starts to sing along:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Around them an infection is spreading: all the women are leading their men. For an instant it is magical, liberating... She leans her head against his shoulder.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They are silent for a moment.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She laughs happily. He joins her, but his seems a little forced. She leans her head on his shoulder and holds him tight. They dance...
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Love is so terrific Such a funny feeling Makes you want to cuddle And coo...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: & HARRY Makes you sentimental, Makes you kinda gentle Ouch! (Frances pinches Harry) Terrific thing.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Why are you always leaving me, Harry?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Huh?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You should stickaround sometimes. Look out for me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Look, Frances, I'm only gonna ask this one time. I mean it. I swear after this, I'll never ask again: Will you marry me?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (after a long pause) I know a thing or two about marriage. You... you understand me more than anyone, Harry... maybe even more than Mama. But... you're too important to me. I'd fail you. I don't know how or why, but I would. And that's a chance I just can't take. Do you understand?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (a bitter smile) Well... I'll act like I do until I do.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: There's just one more thing.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What's that?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Will you marry me?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . FARMER HOUSE - SEATTLE - DAY The Lincoln, Harry at the wheel, drives up and stops. Harry shakes his head.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He laughs. We SEE Lillian come out onto the porch with uncharacteristic trepidation.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She gets out, waves to him, and walks toward the house. Harry drives off. As Frances reaches the top step, Lillian suddenly opens her arms:
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: It's not too late to keep going, up to Vancouver? Be the smartest thing.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Thanks, Harry, really, but... I can't explain it. She's my mother. She's just... I can't give up on her that easy.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You give up on her?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah. It's just... something I gotta do, I guess.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (smiling warmly) Frances, You're crazy.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (whispers) I know. Don't tell anyone.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Anyway... if you need me...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (warmly) I got your number, Mister Man.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (nervous, forced) Welcome home, little sister.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Frances and Lillian enter. On the sofa sits Alma Styles. Alma and Lillian seem slightly furtive. Caught in the act.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She bursts into tears. Frances takes her in her arms and rocks her like a child.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Well, who have we here...?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (anxiously) Frances, you remember my lawyer, Alma Styles?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hello, Frances. You seem to be having quite a time of it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I called Alma because I think we'll need...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Frances, the doctors at Meadow Wood have petitioned the court for your return. Your mother has asked me to intervene so you can stay here.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I swear I didn't know what they were doing to you. I wouldn't have let them...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's okay, Mama. It's okay.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You realize, of course, your mother is now your legal guardian. In the eyes of the law, you no longer have any rights as an adult. You're going to have to hold your tongue and be selective about whom you mix with. That man who drove you here, for instance -- FRANCES You leave him out of this!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Frances, please don't...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Never mind. We won't have to worry about him much longer.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Harry pulls up at a stop sign. He rubs his forehead wearily as a car crosses the intersection. It stops dead in front of him. Another pulls up alongside. Another behind. Harry thinks about this. His hand slides down slowly under the seat. We SEE the handle of his ice pick. Harry turns to smile at the MAN in the next car. The Man flashes an FBI badge, points revolver:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The FBI Man pulls the hammer back on the revolver. ANOTHER MAN opens the passenger door.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (smiling) How ya doin', Al?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You got the wrong guy. Name's Slocum.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No, it ain't. And it ain't Harry York, neither.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Look, I'm tellin' you...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'd give you till ten, Al, but we ain't got the time.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . JUDGE'S CHAMBERS Judge Hillier walking... out of the chamber and down a corridor. His stride is long, his demeanor purposeful. The corridor leads into a courtroom. Harry standing at attention. We hear Hillier climb onto the bench and be introduced by the court official. Harry stares up at the judge.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Alvin Hanson, a.k.a. Ronald Burns, Thomas Slocum, Harry York... Mr. Hanson, this warrant has been outstanding for many years. Normally that circumstance would prompt me toward leniency, but the crime you committed -- inciting to riot -- and the cause you sought to promote -- a worker's rebellion -- are such anathemas to this court that I feel compelled to mete out the full sentence. I only wish it were longer. (slamming gavel) Six months in the state penitentiary.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Frances sits at the piano playing "You Are My Sunshine". Lillian is lounging on the couch, leafing happily through her scrapbook.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Frances' brows mesh.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Frances sighs and begins to play it. Lillian scrunches down and begins to hum along.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She smiles warmly at Frances. Frances abruptly stops playing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She gets up and Lillian rouses herself.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Frances goes down the hall for her coat. Lillian follows part way.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Frances returns wearing the coat. Lillian half-blocking her path.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Lillian nods, moves aside. As Frances heads for the door:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Lillian enters and re-establishes herself on the couch with a happy smile. She begins to hum "Flow Gently Sweet Afton"
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Frances, play 'Flow Gently Sweet Afton'.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh Mama, I'm so... tired of that song.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Please. I want you to. It would make me so happy.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's just a flow gently sweet Afton day. Life has been so good to me. Why, I have just about everything one could wish... but I still have so many blank pages in my scrapbook.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I think I need a little air.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What's wrong?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Nothing. I think I'll just go out for awhile.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Where are you going?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: For a walk, Mama. Just a walk.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: How long will you be?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Not long.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (smiling) I'll have lunch ready by one.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'll be back.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: At one. Promise?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Sure.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Say you promise.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I promise I'll... I promise, Mama.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You know, the surest way to lose an appetite, is to drink, little sister.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (exiting) Yes, Mama.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't want you drinking, Frances.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes, Mama.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: sleep on broken couches and armchairs. In a corner by a pay phone Ernest Farmer sits at a rickety desk piled high with briefs. Frances sits across from him. They've been talking.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Frances rises from her chair, looking around the room to hide her tears. Ernest rises too.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They look at each other across the desk for an uncomfortable moment, then Frances slowly leaves. He looks sadly after her.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: ...So what do you think?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't know, honey. Your mother has such big plans for you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I know that, Dad, but -- ERNEST What you have to understand, Francie, is that she... well... she wanted so much for herself too, and for me, and she never really got to... The only time I ever saw her happy was if her name was in the papers... but she could have been... if times were different she could have been a politician or... I don't know.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: But Dad, I'm asking about me. What do you think I should do?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (after a pause) Well, Francie, sometimes after you get your hands on something you want, it just doesn't look the same. Then you have to be real smart to know if you should hold onto it because it's all you've got... or just let it go. This is the way of things, but I guess you already know that.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Dad... whatever I decide, will it be okay with you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Always. Always.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm sorry, I... I don't have a desk in my room, and... (it's not a proper office)
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't care, Dad. I love you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I love you too, Francie.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Frances exits and starts across the road. Ernest comes to the window to watch her leave. It is raining and the water on the glass distorts his view.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . FARMER HOUSE - FRANCES' ROOM - DAY Lillian is straightening up Frances' room, rearranging things to suit herself. She hears the door slam downstairs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She goes to hug her mother, but Lillian has changed. Frances' news has chilled her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She points to a stack of letters on the table.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Frances grabs her coat.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They're wrestling, Lillian trying to prevent her from leaving.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She grabs Lillian's wrists and twists them, throws her back.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Frances storms out. Lillian sits back in the chair, suddenly looking very old. She massages her wrists...
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (O.S.) I'm back, Mama.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (coming into hall) Oh Frances, do I have news for you! Guess who -- FRANCES (excited) Wait, Mama, wait. I have something to tell you. I've decided... well... I'm not going to make movies anymore. I thought that's what I wanted, and I went after it with all my soul, the way you taught me, but I was miserable, Mama, and it nearly killed me. So now... now it's over. I want a different kind of life, something... simple. I want to live someplace quiet and peaceful... in the country maybe, and I'll have dogs and cats -- I feel so light suddenly, so clear for the first time in... It's going to be okay, Mama, I know it. And I love you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (coming down stairs) Don't... talk crazy.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Mama...?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (entering living room) They want you back! Your agent called today! Don't you understand? He's sending the scripts. He wants to fly up here in a week with the publicity people! Frances, you can't do this to your fans! Why, they've been praying for you all through this nightmare. You can't turn your back on them now! Look at this fan mail I've been answering!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Haven't you heard what I said?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I told him to come up! I told him you wanted to show them all that there's nothing wrong with you any more, that you're completely cured!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm not cured. I was never sick! They had no business putting me in there! My only responsibility is to myself now!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You... you selfish, selfish child. At least talk to him, hear what he has to say.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You want to throw it all away, is that it? You had everything, little sister. Beauty... a brilliant career... a wonderful husband. You were a movie star!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Mama, shut up!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And now you're throwing everything away? You're gonna be a nobody! Nobody! You know what that's like?!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (sudden realization) You... You'd send me back, wouldn't you? You would.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Where are you going?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm going out!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You're not going anywhere!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes, I am, and you can't stop me! You can't tell me what to do, mother. I'm a grown woman, and I can decide about my own life.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Frances!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Don't you try and stop me. Don't you dare!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: If you follow me, Mama, I swear I'll fucking kill you!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's it. You've done it now, little sister.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Dark. Blinds drawn. We SEE a single light with a green shade, HEAR the soft coo of Lillian's voice. The CAMERA SHIFTS gradually onto her earnest face.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: All my life, I've tried to live up to my parents' example. To have the independence of mind and fortitude of spirit that have made this country great. I taught that to Frances: Speak out. Aspire. Make something of yourself, something -- (to be proud of)
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . DOYLE (bored) Yes, yes, Mrs. Farmer -- ALMA STYLES Frances has always been a battleground, Lillian.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . DOYLE, a psychiatrist, and the others are seated with Judge Hillier around a table.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Doyle fills in a line on the printed form before him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Alma holds up Lillian's bruised wrists as evidence.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Alma looks coolly at Lillian.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hillier nods slightly, approvingly, toward Alma.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: The point is: it's your opinion that Frances is getting steadily worse?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well... yes.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And you feel you're unable to control her any longer?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No... I mean, yes, Doctor.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And the only course open to you is to commit your daughter for a period of time to a mental institution?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, Alma told me that...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ...Yes.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (closing his folder) I believe that's all I need to know about Miss Farmer.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I think in all future documents she should be referred to as Mrs. R. H. Richardson.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Her married name?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes. It's less recognizable. I'm sure you'd prefer to keep unpleasant publicity to a minimum.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ...Oh yes.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Now. Can you tell us where we might find Frances?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: It's late. Frances stands at the bar acting out a joke for a small audience of devoted DRINKERS.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Behind them is a large window covered by a gauzy curtain. In the street a police car cruises slowly past.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We SEE the police car again... It stops out front.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: ...Looking for a drink, and the town is deserted, he can't understand it. Finally he finds a bar, goes in -- the place is empty, bartender's closing up. Salesman says, 'Gimme a martini.' Bartender's real nervous, he says, 'No, no, no, I gotta close. Big Otis is coming to town.'
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Salesman says, 'I don't care. I gotta have a martini.' So the bartender fixes him a martini real fast, grabs his money, and runs out the back. Salesman sits there sipping his martini,... he's got the bar all to himself... Then he hears it. This big roaring in the street. RRRAAAAAAA!!! (stomping her feet) Gigantic footsteps... coming closer. Stopping.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Enormous hands reach in, grab the swinging doors and rip them off their hinges. This huge man stomps in. Picks up a chair and hurls it over the bar, smashing the mirror -- whiskey and glass flying everywhere.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: appear at the window, looking in.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Everyone laughs. A long moment of enjoyment. Then Frances turns, looks out the window and sees the cops.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: He turns to the salesman: 'What the hell're you doing in here!' Salesman says, 'I'm just drinking a martini.' 'Oh yeah?' the guy says. 'Well you better get outa here! Big Otis is coming to town!'
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Hillier behind the bench. Doyle sits at a table with Alma Styles. A COURT RECORDER taps out his notes in an odd, jerky style. (NOTE: This scene is INTERCUT, where appropriate, with shots of FRANCES in a bare room, wearing a strait jacket.)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She signs a paper which is passed to Hillier.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He bangs his gavel.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: ...From her history, it's apparent the patient suffers from a paranoid reaction with pronounced egotism. Her violent responses have recently included aggression against her mother. In view of the deep-seated nature of her ailments and her failure to respond satisfactorily to insulin shock, it is my opinion she may ultimately require permanent institutional care.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (to Styles) Counsellor, as Guardian ad litem for Mrs. Richardson, do you waive jury trial?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes, your Honor.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Having heard the testimony of a legally qualified and reputable physician... and being further satisfied of the truth of all matters set forth in the certificates of said physician, I do hereby order that the said Mrs. R. H. Richardson, an insane person, be confined to the Western State Hospital for the Insane at Steilacoom.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: So ordered! Are the gentlemen from Steilacoom present?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Huge, dark-red brick buildings with barred windows, loom out of the fog and trees. A van pulls up to the front entrance. Two MEN get out, open the back doors and assist Frances out. She is strapped into a strait-jacket. She yells and struggles violently but a piercing SCREAM stops her. She looks up at the building. From a top floor window, a thin, white hand protrudes from the bars and waves "hello".
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Frances is dragged kicking and screaming down the shiny linoleum-covered hallway. There are many patients here, talking to imaginary birds, laughing at unheard jokes. A few of them notice Frances, most do not. The two Orderlies arrive at a door and throw it open. A bare 6'10' room is revealed with a narrow cot and no windows. Frances is pushed inside and the door locks shut with a resounding click.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: wheels a small electrical machine up to a table. On the table Frances is securely strapped down. TWO DOCTORS grease Frances' temples and put two metal electrodes on them. The electrodes are connected to the machine.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Doctor #2 nods and jams a rubber bar into Frances' mouth. The Medical Student steps forward.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Doctor #1 shoots a silent query to Doctor #2.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Medical Student pushes the button with great gravity. Frances' body immediately begins to convulse. It seems as if it will never stop.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: #1 What's she getting, anyway?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: #2 Standard series to start.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: #1 Fifteen?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Can I push the button on this one?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: #2 Sure.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Beds three inches apart. Women patients lie on them in varying stages of madness and decay. Some are bound to their beds with coarse cloth strips. One bed is empty, the bonds chewed through. We find Frances sitting on the floor staring at a hissing radiator. Her lips are caked with blood. Her eyes are glazed. She is dreaming. Or remembering...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A scene from one of her movies or plays. Soundless. She looks radiant, vivacious, alive...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ushers Frances and two ATTENDANTS into a sparse tiled room with dilapidated plumbing and fungus growing between the tiles. In the center are three steel baths with hammocks suspended above them. The Attendants strap Frances into a bath as Dr. Doyle enters.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Attendants lower her into the empty tub.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Doctor smiles sympathetically.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As he turns to leave, Frances laughs triumphantly. The two Attendants lower her into the bath and begin to fill it with ice-cold water.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They shove a rubber bit between her teeth. She immediately spits it out and defiantly starts to sing in order to keep her teeth from chattering.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (speaking with difficulty) Doctor, it may sound odd, but I believe I've profited from my stay here. It's just what I've needed, to get away like this. But I'm recuperated now. I've had lots of time to think and I've made a few decisions about my life. I'm ready to get on with it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I know you believe that.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ...Don't you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm afraid not. You see, we observe things that you're unaware of: signs, indicators. Your problem cuts very deep, Frances, and we have to get at that deeper stuff so that when you do get out, you'll really feel secure. Does that make sense?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No. Cut this runaround, Doctor. I know better.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (smiling) Listen to yourself, Frances. The resistance, the anger in your voice.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (tightly) You... I'm sorry, forgive me. Doctor, tell me honestly, what do I have to do to get out of here?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Be patient, that's all. Take an interest in your treatment and don't dwell on your resentments. You'll be yourself again, I assure you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ...I see.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We'll talk more about this. I'll see you later.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: One question. If I'm not myself now, just who do you think I am?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We'll talk.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What the hell!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Everyone eating gruel. A parade of lunatics. The edge of incipient violence is palpable. Frances eats listlessly. Others are playing with their food, devouring it ravenously, fondling each other. Suddenly a call starts up at the far end of the hall. Other voices join in. At first we don't understand it, but gradually the words become clear:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The whole hall joins in. The Nurses make no effort to stop it. Others at Frances' table smile at her, try to push her to her feet. When they succeed, the hall breaks into applause and a new chaotic chant:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The chant is quickly silenced by hushing sounds. Everyone is watching Frances. She climbs up on her bench. Her eyes are glazed, her face expressionless. This feels like some kind of automatic behavior. She takes an exaggerated posture and speaks in almost a whisper:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The hall breaks into riotous applause, catcalls, stomping. Frances climbs down from her bench. That was the entire performance.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Come and get it! Come and get it! Come and get it!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We want Frances! We want Frances!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Come and get it...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Two dark FIGURES move stealthily along the shadow of the main building. A little ways ahead, a door opens, sending a shaft of light across the ground. The two Men duck back into the shadows. Five young SOLDIERS EXIT, paying off and waving goodbye to one of the Orderlies. The door closes. They head off down the road laughing and joking together. The two Men emerge from the shadows and approach the door. They try the handle. It opens. The first one in is Harry, followed by the other Man carrying a rolled-up bundle.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We SEE Harry and the other Man, now wearing a white Doctor's coat, walking quickly down a dim hallway. They come to a large door with a barred window. The Man fiddles with a keyring and unlocks the door. They enter. We HEAR the door lock behind them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Just inside the door the Doctor flicks on a flashlight and they walk down the center of the room. The beam of light sweeps over women PATIENTS in their cots, crammed side-by- side. Some are asleep, others stare blankly at the ceiling. A few smile invitingly at the two Men, whispering obscenities. The light falls on a bedraggled woman hunched over in a corner between the wall and a cot. It is Frances. Harry goes to her, putting his arms around her. She is very heavily sedated. Tears spring to Harry's eyes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Harry is on the verge of tears.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Harry holds her around the shoulders and straightens out her arm. Frances starts to struggle and moan loudly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Harry glares at the Doctor, but puts a hand over her mouth and the Doctor injects her. Her arm is covered with sores.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Doctor withdraws the hypo and massages her arm.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Other women in the ward cry out: "Take me! Take me!!"
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (whispering) Frances! Frances!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Who?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Frances, it's me, Harry?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ...Touch me again and I'll kill you, you pig.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Watch out, Harry. Let me look her over.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, God! Let's get her out of here tonight, right now! Let's take her with us!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The hearing's tomorrow. If she gets out legally, they can't come after her.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Look at her! She'll never pass that sanity test tomorrow...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm taking care of that, Harry. Just hold her. (pulling a hypodermic from his pocket) Reserpine. I guarantee you this'll clear her head. She'll wake up feeling smart and sailright through the hearing.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah... she knows about these. Shut her up.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (tenderly) You'll be okay, honey. He's just givin' you something to make you think, so that tomorrow you can tell 'em what they want to hear, okay? Tell 'em you were crazy as a loon and they cured you and you're grateful.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: This stuff takes pretty quick. Let's go.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (grabbing Harry) Please! Take me!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (pulling Harry) Let's get out of here! I'll lose my job!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Frances, we gotta do it this way. Just remember tomorrow, remember what I told you. What're you gonna tell 'em?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (groggily) I'm grateful... grateful.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm grateful! I'm grateful!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (very worried) Harry!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I gotta go now.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Harry, please!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: The two Men come out and the Doctor quickly locks the door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Frances' face appears at the tiny barred window. We can just hear her:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Behind Frances we HEAR the Women screaming: "I love you, Harry!" The Doctor takes Harry's arm and pulls him down the corridor.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: We're all square now, Harry. Right?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: All square, Doc.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Good. 'Cause I don't want to see you again.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I love you, Harry. I love you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I love you too, Frances.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Frances turns to face the women in their cots. Collects herself. Looks repentant. She is practicing tomorrow's speech.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The others laugh. We realize that if Frances can handle this, she can sail through it tomorrow. The catcalls gradually diminish as she concludes her speech.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The room is silent now. A very odd moment. To their astonishment, the other patients seem to believe her...
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I realize now that I was a very sick woman.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Sick! She's sick!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I couldn't relate to others in a normal way.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (playful warning) She's... not... normal...!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And I was not taking responsibility for my actions. But now, thanks to your treatment, I feel ready to face myself, ready to resume the career which I so single-handedly shattered. I only hope... I hope I can make you all proud of me. Thank you. Thank you so much.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: The vegetable garden is overgrown, the paint peeling. The house is in disrepair, but we can tell from the freshly-mowed lawn that some effort has recently been made... A car pulls up. Frances kisses Ernest on the cheek and gets out. As he drives off, she walks into the yard and looks around, heaves a sigh; she's home. Then Christmas lights spring on over the porch. Lillian comes out grinning broadly, followed by REPORTERS. Frances blanches.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Frances sits on the couch next to Lillian. They're sipping tea and answering questions. Frances is uncomfortable.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She touches it shyly. It's swept up in a continental style.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Lillian laughs.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Of course, she hasn't anything definite in mind.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No. No, it all depends on what offers I get.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Who did your hair, Frances?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, I like to try different styles. Sometimes if you're old-fashioned enough, you find you're modern. Right, Mama?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What do you think of all this, Mrs. Farmer?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's a miracle. Just a miracle.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: The porch light goes out. Shadows pass over the curtained windows. Across the street a match flares. Harry is leaning against a tree. He lights a cigarette and settles back to wait.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Lillian walks from room to room turning off lights. Frances is neatly stacking the dessert dishes on a tray. Very domestic, out of character. She carries the tray into the kitchen.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Lillian smiles warmly at her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Lillian links her arm with Frances' and they go upstairs together.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They hug each other.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Lillian waits until Frances has shut her door before closing hers.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, just leave those things for now.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No, Mama, I'll take care of it. I'll wash them in the morning.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You know, little sister, I never resented you for refusing to see me in the... the hospital. I knew you had to manage on your own before you could come back.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Thank you for understanding, Mama.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Little sister, I don't want you to feel any rush to get back to work. I want you to rest... for a while anyway.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I will, I promise.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Good night, dear.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: The front door opens and Frances, suitcase in hand, slips out onto the porch. She eases the door shut behind her, tiptoes down the steps and, without looking back, starts down the road.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Frances rounds the corner, then sees him: Harry, standing by his car, smiling.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She approaches him tentatively.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Long beat. She turns and stares at him sadly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He nods slowly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They hug. Together for an instant. Then she shivers as if the contact were too much.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He nods, looks at her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He turns and walks slowly to his car.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Where to?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh Harry...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: This is it, kid. This is our chance. When you got a chance, you better take it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah. I don't know.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You don't need to screw around anymore. You don't need Dwayne Steele or Odets or your mother. You need me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I know, but... There were so many people in there, Harry. Every time I turned around someone was pressing against me... watching, looking over my shoulder, touching me, grabbing, sticking things into me. When I feel somebody near me now... anybody... my skin starts to crawl.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You can't change the things they did to me, Harry. Only I can do that... by myself.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Been a lot of years, you know. A long time waiting. For what? End up feeling like a sap.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh please, Harry... don't even think it. You're the only person who ever... It's just... Can't you wait for me?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't know.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (getting frantic) Yes you do. If you love me you can wait, right? A month, six months, whatever it takes.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Right. Except... time has a way of -- FRANCES No, Harry, it's not time, it's us. You and me. And I'm telling you now that I'll come to you, okay? I'll find you. I will.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (smiles wistfully) I hope so, Frances.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (disentangling) I'm sorry.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'll be seeing you, kid.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Barren desert. The middle of nowhere. A lone male HITCHHIKER, poor, stands at a crossroads. A car coming the wrong direction raises dust along the highway. It slows, stops, and lets Frances out. She is now dressed in jeans and a workshirt. She has a heavy tan. She glances across at the Hitchhiker and nods casually. He responds in kind. A relaxed silence follows. Two strangers passing. His voice, when he speaks, is gentle, calm:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Beat.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She stops. She sees now that the car heading toward her is a cop car. She averts her face... then tries to hide her gesture.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Frances sighs as the cop car speeds away.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She's uncertain whether to trust him. Takes the plunge:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He laughs. She shivers slightly, pulls her clothes around her. He takes out a small flask and offers, no strings:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She smiles, truly grateful:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Then she sees a ball of dust nearing... a car on his side.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The car stops. Its lights flashing. COPS jump out.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She does. She's pursued. The Hitchhiker makes an effort to impede the Cops' progress, but is tossed aside. The Cops are slowly, inevitably, gaining on her.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Pretty morning.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (nods) It's always beautiful at this time. Peaceful...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And no people.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Where you goin'?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Wherever they're going, I'm going.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah, I know what that's like... Where you been?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, I was picking fruit with some migrant workers until...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What's the matter?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: They're looking for you, huh?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What'd you do?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You know, I've never been able to figure that out.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I've got a little whiskey here, warm you up.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Thank you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Wait. Maybe they'll pick you up.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Shit!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Run!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Frances and Ernest walk out the door followed by a portly SHERIFF. He watches them get in Ernest's car and drive off. His expression says very clearly: I'm glad that's over with.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ernest's at the wheel, Frances at his side. Silence, then:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ernest writhes slightly with discomfort.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We SEE them approaching a side road.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They are nearer the side road.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They pass the side road. It disappears behind them. All the life seems to drain from Frances.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Frances buries her face in her hands.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Dad...? Why don't you stop at a side road and let me out?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Francie, you know I can't do that.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Why? It's such a simple thing. You just let me out and I disappear down a road and you never have to see me again.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: They'll just catch you again, Francie. Besides, your mother will know.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Dad, here! You don't have to stop, just slow down. You can tell Mama I jumped out. She knows that's the kind of thing I'd do. She won't blame you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: But I gave her my word. Besides, she's still your legal guardian. My hands are tied.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You know where you're taking me. You know what she'll do. Just give me a minute, slow down, give me an instant for once in your life, please?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Please, Francie...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (pleading) Daddy!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'll try to protect you, Francie. I will, I'll talk to her. We'll have a real talk.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Are you... are you hungry?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I pity us, Dad. I pity us both.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Lillian is sitting on the couch, waiting. We HEAR A CAR PULL UP outside and stop. Doors slam. Steps come up the walk and onto the porch. The door opens and Frances and Ernest enter. Lillian rises to face her daughter.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Through the window we SEE a white van pull up outside.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The way she goes out that door we know she's never coming back.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (coldly) Do I go right away or do I have time to take a bath?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I was hoping for a kind word, little sister.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You were hoping for a kind word?! You're my mother! You're supposed to nourish me! Support me!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I have!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No! All you've done is try to break my spirit, try to turn me into you! But I'm not you, mother, and I never will be, and thank god for it! (to Ernest) That goes for you too! And frankly, I don't know how, with the two of you, I turned out as sane as I am -- (to the MEN IN WHITE COATS who are at the door) Wait right there, gentlemen, I'll be with you in a minute... and believe me, I don't want to stay here one second longer than I have to! (turning back) But I've got to tell you, Lillian, that one day before you die, you will realize what you've done and hang your head in shame. In shame!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: But what -- (have I done?)
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No! You're not talking now. You listen. You can send me away, Lillian, you can pretend I'm crazy and pretend I'm still your little girl who can't take care of herself, but one thing you can't pretend anymore. You can't pretend I love you because I don't. I can't. Not after what you've done to me. Because you see... I'm still me... I'm trying real hard all this time to be me... and you, 'little sister', you haven't been any help at all. (walking out the door) Okay, boys, I'm ready.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: The ward is a huge room packed with nearly naked women, their hair cropped very short. The walls are corrugated tin nailed to bare wood framing. The place looks like an enormous tool shed. The SOUND OF GARBLED VOICES and SCREAMING never stops. These are the forgotten ones... beyond hope. Everyone here has lost any notion of what they might have once been. Their faces are slack, only their eyes glow with an animal ferocity. Some wander aimlessly about, unheeding of others who are pushing, kicking and screaming at them. Many squat in the dirt by the walls, mired in their own urine and excrement, chanting wordlessly to themselves. Some appear lifeless, their prone bodies shoved out of the way. Some women are involved in violent sex with themselves or each other, some in mindless fist-fights. In a far corner we SEE a group of men in various military and medical uniforms, their backs to us, facing the wall, grouped around something. We HEAR their cheering and laughing and joking, slapping each other on the back. We SLOWLY MOVE CLOSER and can see over their shoulders the object of their hilarity. It's Frances, lying naked and spread- eagled on the floor. Four hospital ATTENDANTS pin her arms and legs. A SOLDIER, his pants down around his ankles, is squirming violently on top of her. Frances' eyes are open but glazed, her face turned away from her attacker. She is passive and unresisting. She is reciting to herself, over and over.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Two of the SOLDIERS, waiting their turn, are smoking cigarettes and chatting idly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Frances keeps reciting as one rapist gets off. The Soldiers cheer as another quickly takes his place.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: We shall hear the angels, we shall see the whole sky all diamonds...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: #1 ...Best deal I ever made. Twenty bucks to fuck a fuckin' movie star.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: #2 Yeah, it's worth it I guess.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: #1 What's she saying, anyway?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: #2 Who knows. She's crazy, ain't she?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: A heavy snow is falling. From the corrugated-tin Violent Ward, a thin white hand protrudes from a narrow window to catch a snowflake. As it opens and closes, capturing individual flakes, a VOICE BEGINS TO SING "You Are My Sunshine...". We recognize Frances' voice, still surprisingly strong and steady.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: discuss Frances' condition as we SEE, background, that she is getting electroshock treatments from a pair of doctors.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I don't know why they even bother. She's had enough of this to knock sense into a bull elephant.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (nods) I checked the files. This one holds the record for shock treatments. Four hundred seventeen and no end in sight.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (wincing) You're kidding.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (indicating the doctors) Yeah, well, you know doctors. They sure hate to use that word.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: 'Incurable.'
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . STEILACOOM - HOLDING WARD - DAY Frances, barely conscious, lies strapped to a bed. Doyle and an ORDERLY approach her. Doyle nods toward her as if to say: that one. He and the Orderly unstrap her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She's untied. The Orderly helps her up onto a gurney. She lies down. Doyle nods to the Orderly, who starts pushing her. She is wheeled out and down:
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (to Doyle) Harry? Oh Harry, I knew you'd come. I love you, Harry. I love... Take me home, Harry.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We'll get you home, Frances.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Thank you, Harry.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Past other patients, doctors, etc. We see some of this from her point of view. She goes through two swinging doors, down another hall... at the end of which a man opens a door. She is pushed onto a:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She is wheeled into a row... between two other patients. In the background we HEAR a voice:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The lights are bright, on her and the other patients. We cannot see, but we sense, an audience watching.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Frances stares up at a fan in the ceiling. It's moving round and round. The voice drones on.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We now see vaguely that DR. HARLINGTON has moved to the patient on the adjacent gurney.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Frances turns and stares mutely, without emotion, at what's happening next to her: the leucotome (an ice-pick-like instrument) is inserted into a woman's eye socket...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The leucotome is then shoved up into the brain and twisted.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Frances turns away and stares at the fan again. There is something simple and pleasing about its rhythmic whirring...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We glimpse the leucotome being withdrawn.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Harlington's face moves vaguely into Frances' view.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He moves directly over Frances, his pleasant face obscuring the fan. As the leucotome descends, we:
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: . HARLINGTON (O.S.) One merely inserts the leucotome beneath the eyelid and presses up into the prefrontal lobe, manipulating it so as to sever the nervous connections between the thalamofrontal radiation and the body of the brain.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . HARLINGTON (O.S.) Because of the speed and simplicity of the operation, I am able, as you are seeing, to perform the procedure on ten patients in less than a half hour.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . HARLINGTON (O.S.) The operation is completely painless and can be performed without any sedative whatsoever.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . HARLINGTON We have always known that this form of radical treatment was effective, but until now it couldn't be applied on a large scale. The old procedure required a full day's work by a surgical team to perform a single operation. In the same time, working alone, I can treat fifty.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . HARLINGTON This procedure works best on patients with extreme over-reactions to emotional stimuli. It can also be used as a last resort on those who seem impervious to other forms of treatment.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . HARLINGTON In plain language, my technique severs the nerves which give emotional energy to ideas. Along with the cure comes a loss of affect... a kind of emotional flattening...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . HARLINGTON ...with diminished creativity and imagination. Patients become like good solid cake with no icing. But, after all, it is their emotions and imaginations that are disturbed.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . HARLINGTON These patients will soon be leaving the hospital.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . HARLINGTON Lobotomy gets 'em home.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Total disrepair: peeling paint, broken steps, fallen shingles... This house is easing slowly back to nature...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Neglect is just as evident inside. Dust, faded rugs, torn yellow curtains. Lillian sits on the couch staring out a window. She has aged and looks tiny, frail, with no trace of her old formidability. The scrapbook is open on her lap.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ernest is hunched in a chair by the stone fireplace. FOUR REPORTERS crouch on the floor, totally bored. Yesterday's headlines are now old news.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Two Reporters rise and edge toward the door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The last Reporter gets to his feet.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He follows the others out. Lillian climbs wearily to her feet and goes to the window, looks out. Ernest stares into the fire.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ernest looks at her wearily, as if she is stark raving mad. He knows damn well Frances isn't coming home...
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: What was I saying? Oh yes, it was the Communists that did it to Frances.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: They capture the mind by first seducing the heart. I suppose I never taught Frances to close her heart...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Uh... excuse us, Mrs. Farmer. We're going to have to... uh...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (rising) Yeah, I better pack it in too.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (distractedly) Pardon? Oh, would you like more lemonade?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (kindly) I think we've had enough. Thank you, Mrs. Farmer. Goodbye.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You know, Ernie, I think we should have Frances' room repainted for when she comes home. That'll brighten her day.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: : A TELEVISION SCREEN against a dark background The show is "This Is Your Life". We SEE a smiling RALPH EDWARDS, reading from a large black book. Next to him stands Frances. She has aged dramatically, but is still a very handsome woman. She seems uncomfortable.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Throughout this, Frances' jaw works slowly back and forth, not from anger, but in embarrassment and doubt.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We MOVE AWAY from the screen to see that the TV set is in the living room of a comfortable, tastefully furnished home. On the couch in front of the set sits Harry York. He still looks athletic, young for his age. Tears stream down his cheeks.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: ...Dwayne Steele divorced you, and from this point on, your story takes a darker turn. Shunned by the Hollywood you criticized so harshly, alienated from your family and friends, you turn your back on professional commitments in New York, and alcohol and drugs enter your life. These are sad, desperate times for you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ...until finally your mother finds it necessary to commit you to a state mental institution. Were you mentally ill, Frances?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ...No, Ralph. I don't believe I ever was sick. But when you're treated like a patient long enough, you're apt to act like one...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (O.S.) Were you an alcoholic?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (O.S.) No.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (O.S.) Were you a drug addict?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (O.S.) No. Never.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Edwards has moved Frances over to a seating area where various people from Frances' life are waiting, smiling at her. We've never seen any of them before.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The curtains behind them open to reveal a car in a spotlight.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The audience applauds. Frances smiles guardedly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Applause.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The audience applauds. Frances smiles wearily and accepts congratulations.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: ...and over 200 producers have been invited to watch your appearance here tonight... so who knows, Frances Farmer, anything's possible on your comeback trail! (indicating seating area) And since your friends tell me they have to drive you everywhere, look what we've got for you!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: A brand new 1958 Edsel!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Thank you, Ralph.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Thank you, Frances. And after the show we're hosting a reception for you and your friends at Hollywood's own Roosevelt Hotel!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: So, Frances Farmer, this is your life. Good night. God bless you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: A group of PEOPLE are coming down the front steps, Frances among them. They all talk happily, Frances is silent but smiling.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The people all excuse themselves, calling goodbye. Frances waits by herself for a few moments, but soon begins to walk away down the sidewalk.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She turns. Harry is leaning against the side of a building, looking much as he did when they first met. But there is very little light of recognition in Frances' eyes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Harry is a little puzzled by her reaction.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They are both silent a long moment.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Harry is alarmed now.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She angrily bares her teeth; then just as suddenly she relaxes and becomes lucid.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Beat. She takes his hand as if to shake it. Harry clasps hers tenderly. She holds on like an old woman, stroking his hand. For an instant she gets lost in time, just holding his hand. Then she looks up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It is as if she is able to express in words the last remnant of her indomitable will... but the words bear no emotional power.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He offers his arm. She takes it. All rather formal. They stroll on together.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Where shall we drop you, Frances? Home?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (vaguely) No... no, someone's picking me up.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (O.S.) Hey.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: C'mere. I want to talk to you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (flatly) Oh. Why, Harry York. How nice to see you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: How... how ya doin', Farmer?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Fine, thank you. Did you watch the show?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Sure I did, that's why I'm here.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (concerned) How did I look?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, you... (smiling) ...ennh.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (a glimmer, but she does not pick up on the cue) Well... you're looking well.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I got a new car. Only it's red. Did you know Mama died?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah. Yeah, I heard about that.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Dad, too. I sold the house. I'm a faceless sinner, Harry...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Why do you say that?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'd ask you to take me home, but I'm a faceless sinner. (she smiles) ...You smell good, Harry. Familiar, you know? I'd ask you to take me home, but...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (taking her by the arm) Frances!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Don't get mad at me, Harry. Please. It's just... Some things happen for the best.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's going to be slow from now on. Do you know what I mean, Harry?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm not sure.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Very slow. (uncertainly) But we're not going to stop, are we?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (reassured) No, we're not.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Goodbye, Harry. It was very good to see you again.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes. Would you like me to walk a little way with you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That would be okay.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Just a little way.
dialogue.name: dialogue
